newsitem.title: CHILE: FOCUS-Chile Chuquicamata supervisors accept offer.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Chile Chuquicamata supervisors accept offer.

text.p: Supervisors at Codelco's Chuquicamata copper mine voted Tuesday to accept a company pay offer but a sizable minority of votes in favor of striking showed there was only grudging acceptance of the deal, union leaders said.
A total of 354 agreed to accept the new four-year wage contract and 196 voted to strike out of 553 votes cast, said a union spokesmen at the mine, Codelco's largest.
"I think it's good that so many workers voted against the pay offer because it shows we are unhappy with many aspects of it," said Grimaldo Ponce, president of the 670-member supervisors' union.
Still, most workers at assembly in Chuquicamata said the wages offered in the contract were good and that they were happy with the agreement apart from the health insurance provisions.
"The result of this vote indicates that the wage offer is good," said Ponce.
He said workers were unhappy with a provision of the pay contract awarding health care -- currently the responsibility of Codelco -- to a private insurance company created by Codelco.

"There was a question of principles here. We don't want a private health insurance group running our health care. It is a historical aberration." said a worker, who declined to give his name and said he voted against the wage contract.
The new wage contract is the first ever reached by collective bargaining between management and the supervisors' union.
The company offered a four-year contract including a 3.5 percent real wage rise, plus a further nine percent rise conditional on reaching production targets.
Chuquicamata's 7,000 miners went on strike for 10 days last year after scheduled wage talks broke down.
The mine, the largest of Codelco's four mining divisions, produced 632,000 tonnes of fine copper in 1996.
